clinical_study.brief_title: Cardiopulmonary Effects of Intrathoracic Pressure Overshoot During Carbon Dioxide Insufflation in Thoracoscopic Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Cardiopulmonary Effects of Intrathoracic Pressure Overshoot During Carbon Dioxide Insufflation in Thoracoscopic Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: Daping Hospital and the Research Institute of Surgery of the Third Military Medical University

clinical_study.source: Daping Hospital and the Research Institute of Surgery of the Third Military Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) has become a standard technique for addressing all types of thoracic pathology. Insufflation of carbon dioxide (CO2) into the operated chest cavity could increase lung collapse and improve surgical field view. The actual thoracic pressure values may not be identical with the presetting on the insufflator display. This overshoot pressure during VATS may compromise cardiac and pulmonary function. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effects of intrathoracic pressure overshoot during two-lung ventilation on the hemodynamic and respiratory function and clarify the relative safety of two different techniques of insufflation.

primary_outcome.description: Time and value of thoracic pressure overshoot during CO2 insufflation
Hemodynamic changes during each overshoot including Systolic Blood Pressure, Central Venous Pressure and Heart Rate
Respiratory changes during each overshoot including Peak Inspiratory Pressure, Pressure flat, Arterial Oxygen Saturation and End-tidal Carbon dioxide

intervention.description: After patients were positioned, CO2 was insufflated into right pleural cavity at eight or sixteen L/min. during video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery, thoracic pressure, hemodynamic and respiratory parameters were recorded.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Ⅰ,Ⅱ
- Patients with esophageal carcinoma
- Elective video-assisted thoracic surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergic to drugs used in the study
- Refusal of VAST
- Arrhythmia or treated with antiarrhythmic drug
